SafetyInspectionBy: Fire Marshall - SC Dept of LP Gas Board

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill alarm at 80% with auto. Shutoff at 85%, min. class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (truck offloading) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detectors, flow monitoring, temperature, pressure & liquid level indicators
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installed windsock, additional security lighting and surveillance cameras
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pump, Bartec Unit, vessel/pipe integrity, ESD's; Alarm, pressure reliefs
_prev_prog_3.Description: Butane (2x90,000 gallons pus lines, liquefied and stored under pressure), blending system involving direct injection into refined product (gasoline) pipelines with bulk truck offloading.  System operations are anticipated to occur primarily during the A?coldA? season.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Kinder Morgan Southwest Terminals LLC - North Augusta #2 Terminal Butane Blending System was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) #58 (2008 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes.  It is the intent of the North Augusta #2 Terminal to incorporate the most recent construction and procedural guidance (NFPA # 58-2008 Edition) into this process.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Belvedere Fire Department as well as the Aiken County Emergency Management Division.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the local Emergency Medical Services (Aiken County Ambulance Service) and University Hospital - Augusta.

Kinder Morgan Southeast Terminals LLC - North Augusta #2 Terminal is a bulk petroleum storage and distribution facility that includes butane blending operations.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane blending system, including the associated piping and two 90,000 gallon butane storage vessels. 

The facility's worst case scenario is the failure of one of the system's two 90,000 gallon butane storage vessels when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% fill shut-off with alarm at 80%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The facility's alternate (potential for off-site impacts) release scenario is a "BLEVE" accident and associated fireball.

Kinder Morgan Southeast Terminals LLC - North Augusta #2 Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) along with its fourteen (14) compliance elements, and all applicable state and local laws and regulations.  The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufactu

rer's (Sunoco Partners Butane Blending, LLC)

As this is a new system, this facility has never had an accident involving the butane process which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.

In the event of an emergency involving the Kinder Morgan Southeast Terminals LLC - North Augusta #2 Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Belvedere Fire Department (Primary Responder) and request their assistance.  The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with fire department and the Aiken County Emergency Management.  The Belvedere Fire Department has participated in the initial RMP/PSM training session for this system.

Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point pneumatic valve feeds to pneumatic valves (fail closed), 85% fill shut-off (80% alarm and 90% ESD actuation) on the vessels, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding interlock devices.  

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Kinder Morgan Southeast Terminals LLC looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements.  Additionally, the Belvedere Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills.  Additional actions include consolidating separate system inspection checklists for ease of completion.
